posts.cooked:
This past year we switched to using Rio2.0 because our code simply would not run with the memory available on the Rio1.0.

I wanted to see if folks out there are still able to run swerve and vision (either LL or PV ) with a Rio1.0 and if there are optimizations which allowed you to do so.

We have a plethora of Rio1.0, and are not eager to invest in more Rio2.0 with a new system coming in 2027. Any advice on how to continue being able to use Rio1.0, especially for simpler robots for our second team (429) would be appreciated.

Big one is obviously not doing all the logging we currently do…but we really really value being able to run Advantage Kit. Anyone able to run a decent bit of logging on the 1.0?

link_counts.title: 6328's Advanced Swerve Drive Example Lagging on RobotRIO 1.0

posts.cooked: We swapped too this year, literally just for better loop times. And did very little  logging to further reduce loop times.

posts.name: Drew Williams
posts.cooked:
We have no issues using the rio 1. We log a ton of values. We also used photonvision and choreo and logged everything during real matches.

The difference is we use C++ This allows us to keep loop times low. I know switching to C++ isn’t an option for a lot of teams, but Java as a language just isn’t meant for such a low power processor especially with all the logging and heap allocations teams are doing these days.

My advice is to try to profile and see if you are doing massive allocations anywhere. wpidocs has a page on java garbage collection ( Java Garbage Collection — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation )

link_counts.title: Java Garbage Collection — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
We ran RoboRIO 2.0s in season on 3847 & 8515.

This off-season we had a third robot running the same code base on a roboRIO 1.0.

We did the system tuning on this page

Java garbage collection is the process of automatically managing memory for Java objects. The Java Virtual Machine (JVM) is responsible for creating and destroying objects, and the garbage collecto...

And we’re able to get through the off-season without OOM issues during matches or during normal tuning and testing.

link_counts.title: Java Garbage Collection — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked: We ran 1.0s, and definitely had issues with loop overruns.  We were able to tune some settings to preserve memory (same link as @AllenGregoryIV ), but it still isn’t perfect, especially at startup.  I’m not sure what has put more stress on the RIO than previous years, but logging, swerve and “improvements” to WPILib all probably share the blame.   It’s hard to justify upgrading to RIO 2.0s when we’re so close to a complete new control system, but we might be running out of choice in the matter

link_counts.title: Java Garbage Collection — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked: We were having some loop overruns on our comp robots on Rio 2.0s as well, and still did on the 1.0.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
Our main robot ran a RIO 2.0, but our development robot with swerve + vision pose estimation and ran a RIO 1.0 just fine.

We had far more advanced code on our RIO 1.0 robot in 2023 than this year and it worked fine. We don’t do a ton of logging yet would be the main thing we do not do from what you asked and the logging we do run is just Phoenix loggers.

posts.name: bobbysq
posts.cooked:
nuclearnerd:

We ran 1.0s, and definitely had issues with loop overruns. We were able to tune some settings to preserve memory (same link as @AllenGregoryIV ), but it still isn’t perfect, especially at startup.

Would it be feasible to use a swap partition on a flash drive to avoid OOM errors? USB 2.0 certainty isn’t fast enough that it’s any good as extra RAM, but if startup is the problem, maybe it would give a bit of wiggle room for that period while there aren’t timing-critical things going on.

posts.name: Mike
posts.cooked: We ran into some issues With OOM on java on the rio 1. We did end up using the memory optimizations documented by WPILib and they helped the problem quite a bit. That said we did not monitor our loop times and the constancy of them, so it is very possible we where experiencing hitching/slowdowns. Nothing big enough for us to notice when driving.  I have been on the fence about getting a RIO2 as it seems like it would give us a little bit more headroom.

posts.name: Mike
posts.cooked:
Yes, we used that this year.

Java garbage collection is the process of automatically managing memory for Java objects. The Java Virtual Machine (JVM) is responsible for creating and destroying objects, and the garbage collecto...

link_counts.title: Java Garbage Collection — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked:
Mike_Combs:

I have been on the fence about getting a RIO2 as it seems like it would give us a little bit more headroom.

My only warning is that we have found the rio2 to be way more prone to shorting due to any sort of tiny debris, which did not used to affect our rio1 as much. That plus the fact that a team can only order one a season from AndyMark makes things tough. That’s one of the other reasons I want to keep using our Rio1’s as long as possible on some of the robots.

We had to tape up and retape every single gap in the rio2 case including ziptie holes, way more tightly than in the past for the rio1 to help with this. I saw a bunch of teams make sure to mount them sideways if possible as well.
Have you tried diy conformal coating it? with hot glue or something better
Nah but I did look into it! Just never had the time or guts to maybe accidentally mess something up

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
nuclearnerd:

… and “improvements” to WPILib all probably share the blame.

I think the main factor is the migration from JDK 11’s CMS garbage collector to JDK 17’s G1 garbage collector for the 2023 season, then to the serial garbage collector for the 2024 season. We had to migrate at some point since newer JDKs dropped CMS, but G1 isn’t designed for a 887 MHz CPU and 512 MB of RAM, and serial has some tuning issues. The lower overhead GCs available in newer JDKs don’t support ARM32 (let alone softfp), so we have to wait for the new ARM64 control system in 2027.

wpimath also has several GC-intensive classes that were added way back in 2020, but teams likely only started using them recently. We don’t have something like a remote roboRIO to do profiling on, so it really helps if teams report performance issues they see in a VisualVM session. Fixes typically involve writing out math the long way (Rotation3d.rotateBy() in #5525 ) or calling the C++ version through JNI (Pose3d.exp(), Pose3d.log() in #5444 ) because linear algebra in Java is verbose, slow, and memory-intensive. We try to avoid JNIs because they’re verbose and annoying to write, but we do what we have to do to work around how bad Java is in constrained environments.

posts.name: Mike
posts.cooked: Is the rio2 not conformal coated? I could have sworn that the rio1 had a coating over the main board.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
calcmogul:

887 MHz CPU and 512 MB of RAM

Since we’re talking Rio 1, you mean 667 MHz and 256 MB of RAM, but yeah.

To the broader point, we learned a lot this year (thus the documentation page) and should be able to implement a number of those tweaks by default for 2025.  The simple fact is that teams are doing more than ever before with a controller that was released 10 years ago.  The fact that it’s held up as well as it has is frankly amazing, although it’s required a lot of workarounds by the WPILib team to keep it usable.  No disputing that the next couple of years are going to be hard—teams will keep pushing to do more, but the Rio 1 is past EOL.

posts.name: Asher Olgeirson
posts.cooked: We’re a C++ team we work perfectly fine with Rio 1s. We get loop overruns on both systems though, although it’s totally manageable.

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
calcmogul:

I think the main factor is the migration from JDK 11’s CMS garbage collector to JDK 17’s G1 garbage collector for the 2023 season, then to the serial garbage collector for the 2024 season. We had to migrate at some point since newer JDKs dropped CMS, but G1 isn’t designed for a 887 MHz CPU and 512 MB of RAM, and serial has some tuning issues. The lower overhead GCs available in newer JDKs don’t support ARM32 (let alone softfp), so we have to wait for the new ARM64 control system in 2027.

If these deficiencies are known, why are we not freezing the JDK requirements to version 11 or older, at least until 2027?

posts.name: Dkt01
posts.cooked: 1756 is also still running the OG RoboRIO with C++.  We have logging with WPILog and CTRE hoot logs to a USB drive and loop times seem manageable.  Never had memory issues.  We have a decent supply of RoboRIO 1.0s and I appreciate the robustness of the onboard storage, so we haven’t had a big motivation to switch.  Probably going to hold out until the 2027 control system refresh

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Multiple variables changed, so we can’t say for sure it’s due to JDK 17.  We actually held back upgrading for several years to enable teams to downgrade if they so chose, but very few teams even tried it.  Teams started doing a lot more logging (increased native memory pressure and CPU usage), AprilTag processing (Limelight, for example, sends JSON data and parsing that is very memory-intensive), loading tons of auto paths (JSON and memory intensive) and swerve (lots more small math objects) at about the same time as the change, so it’s hard to tell if the old JDK would have fared better or worse—downgrading may actually make things worse .
